==Definitions==
 
==Definitions==
−
"Wisdom is the application of knowledge and experience as guided by common sense." [S. Roditi]
  −    
[[Charles Haddon Spurgeon]] defined wisdom to be "the right use of [[knowledge]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=Charles Spurgeon|url=https://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/Charles_Spurgeon#Quotes|publisher=Wikiquote|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> [[Robert I. Sutton]] and [[Andrew Hargadon]] defined the "attitude of wisdom" to be "acting with knowledge while doubting what one knows."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Carney|first1=Brian M.|last2=Getz|first2=Isaac|title=Freedom, Inc.|date=2009|publisher=Crown Business|isbn=9780307462473|page=238|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J3nVgNxrvlwC&lpg=PA238&ots=sqbFWLiosK&dq=Wisdom%20acting%20knowledge%20doubting&pg=PA238#v=onepage&q=Wisdom%20acting%20knowledge%20doubting&f=false|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
 
[[Charles Haddon Spurgeon]] defined wisdom to be "the right use of [[knowledge]]".<ref>{{cite web|title=Charles Spurgeon|url=https://en.wikiquote.org/wiki/Charles_Spurgeon#Quotes|publisher=Wikiquote|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref> [[Robert I. Sutton]] and [[Andrew Hargadon]] defined the "attitude of wisdom" to be "acting with knowledge while doubting what one knows."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Carney|first1=Brian M.|last2=Getz|first2=Isaac|title=Freedom, Inc.|date=2009|publisher=Crown Business|isbn=9780307462473|page=238|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J3nVgNxrvlwC&lpg=PA238&ots=sqbFWLiosK&dq=Wisdom%20acting%20knowledge%20doubting&pg=PA238#v=onepage&q=Wisdom%20acting%20knowledge%20doubting&f=false|accessdate=8 March 2015}}</ref>
